docs.snippet: Photograph of a suspicious building in Burma that has some intelligence experts worried in light of reports about possible transfer of nuclear reactor technology from North Korea....
docs.lead_paragraph: In my Thursday column, I referred to reports that North Korea may have supplied a plutonium nuclear reactor, suitable for proliferation, to Burma. Here is a photo of a suspect Burmese building that concerns intelligence experts. As you can see, it is near a river -- like the 5 MWe reactor in Yongbyon, North Korea, whose basic design was copied and built in Syria as well. The building has large power lines feeding it. And it's certainly an unusual building to have in a remote part of impoverished Burma. This is from Google, taken this year; I've compared it to earlier Google photos, but of course the key difference is what is going on inside the building. Anybody know any more about this building? (Update: here's an analysis from Arms Control Wonk.)

headline.main: Suspect Building in Burma

docs.abstract: Photograph of a suspicious building in Burma that has some intelligence experts worried in light of reports about possible transfer of nuclear reactor technology from North Korea.

docs.snippet: Yahoo looks at search differently than Google and Microsoft do. Google and Microsoft want to have stand-alone search franchises that function as helpers for our brains. If you are hunting for something specific, you hit Google or Microsoft's Bing ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo looks at search differently than Google and Microsoft do. Google and Microsoft want to have stand-alone search franchises that function as helpers for our brains. If you are hunting for something specific, you hit Google or Microsoft's Bing in the hopes of finding an answer. Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo's chief executive, right, places Yahoo's position in a rather different light. ''We have never been a search company,'' she said. ''It is, 'I am on Yahoo. I am going to do a search.' ''

headline.main: Search Service? Not Yahoo, Says Chief Executive

docs.snippet: Google Sky Map, a free app available only on Android phones, merges a phone's GPS and compass with date and time to show you a map of the sky from where you are standing. It charts stars, constellations, planets and Messier objects (that's basical...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google Sky Map, a free app available only on Android phones, merges a phone's GPS and compass with date and time to show you a map of the sky from where you are standing. It charts stars, constellations, planets and Messier objects (that's basically everything else in the sky), oriented with or without a grid and horizon line. Rotate the phone and celestial bodies pan by. Manual mode lets you move the map without waving the handset.

headline.main: App of the Week: A Free Guide for Stargazers

docs.abstract: Gadgetwise blog highlights Google Sky Map, free app available on T-Mobile's Android phones; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Google plans to begin offering loan quotes online as early as this month, a lawsuit filed in federal court this week claims. Google is not a party to the case.

docs.snippet: Life as a small private company offering online word processors, spreadsheets and e-mail -- just like the mighty Google -- would seem perilous indeed.     And now Microsoft plans to jump into this market, too. The company said last month that it w...
docs.lead_paragraph: Life as a small private company offering online word processors, spreadsheets and e-mail -- just like the mighty Google -- would seem perilous indeed. And now Microsoft plans to jump into this market, too. The company said last month that it would offer basic online Office programs, free and supported by ads, along with the next version of its productivity suite, Office 2010.

headline.main: Zoho Thrives Amid the Giants

docs.abstract: Zoho, based in Pleasanton, Calif, is making solid profit despite fact that it is small private company that offers online word processing, spreadsheets and e-mail just like Google; blogger comments; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Google plans to begin offering online loan quotes as early as September, a lawsuit filed in federal court last week claimed. The suit was filed by LendingTree, which offers consumers mortgage quotes and conditional loan offers online, against Mort...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google plans to begin offering online loan quotes as early as September, a lawsuit filed in federal court last week claimed. The suit was filed by LendingTree, which offers consumers mortgage quotes and conditional loan offers online, against Mortech, a company that provides some of the technology that powers the LendingTree service. Google is not a party to the case. But according to the complaint, filed in United States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina, Mortech plans to make its technology available to Google, which, in turn, plans to release a service to compete with LendingTree. The complaint alleges that would be a violation of a contract between LendingTree and Mortech.

headline.main: Mortgage Quote by Google?

docs.abstract: Suit filed by LendingTree against Mortech claims that Google, which is not party to case, plans to begin offering online mortgage loan quotes as early as September; bloggers comment (S)
